I have a question about the kata titled "Uniform convergence mean [sic] we can swap limits!" I successfully completed the kata, but I believe that the statement that the instructions claim is being proved does not quite make sense and arguably does not agree with the formal statement in the kata.

Here is the statement from the instructions of the kata (mildly paraphrased): If ⟨fn⟩\langle f_n \rangle⟨fn​⟩ is a sequence of functions R→R\R \to \RR→R which converge uniformly to a function ggg then for any aaa, lim⁡n→∞lim⁡x→afn(x)=lim⁡x→alim⁡n→∞fn(x)\lim_{n \to \infty}\lim_{x \to a} f_n(x) = \lim_{x \to a}\lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x)limn→∞​limx→a​fn​(x)=limx→a​limn→∞​fn​(x). The problem is basically that there is no reason to assume that the limits lim⁡x→afn(x)\lim_{x \to a}f_n(x)limx→a​fn​(x) or lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x \to a}g(x)limx→a​g(x) exist.

The formal statement in the kata explicitly assumes that lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x \to a}g(x)limx→a​g(x) exists and implicitly assumes the limits lim⁡x→afn(x)\lim_{x \to a}f_n(x)limx→a​fn​(x) do all exist and that lim⁡x→afn(x)=fn(a)\lim_{x \to a}f_n(x) = f_n(a)limx→a​fn​(x)=fn​(a). With these assumptions, the statement basically becomes trivial; the only thing to show is that lim⁡x→ag(x)=g(a)\lim_{x \to a}g(x) = g(a)limx→a​g(x)=g(a). And it doesn't require uniform convergence of the fnf_nfn​'s to ggg, just convergence at aaa.

If you don't assume the limits exist then the statement doesn't make sense and it is not possible to prove that they exist even if you assume that lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x \to a}g(x)limx→a​g(x) exists. (Of course, if you assume that lim⁡x→afn(x)\lim_{x \to a}f_n(x)limx→a​fn​(x) exists for each nnn then you can prove that lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x \to a}g(x)limx→a​g(x) also exists but this is not what the kata asks you to do.)

In summary: I think the only way I can think of to interpret the statement in the kata's instructions so that it's not false or trivial is as "a uniformly convergent sequence of functions which are all continuous at a point converge to something which is also continuous at that point." But this is not the formal statement found in the kata.

Sorry about the confusion! I see what you mean!

I think I now understand the root of the problem with this kata. The problem is that the formal definition of limit given in the kata is not the usual one and it makes the kata more trivial than it's supposed to be

The formal definition of limit of a function at a point given in the kata is

lim⁡x→af(x)=l  ⟺  ∀ϵ>0 ∃δ>0 ∀x ∣x−a∣<δ  ⟹  ∣f(x)−l∣<ϵ.\lim_{x \to a}f(x) = l \iff \forall \epsilon > 0\, \exists \delta > 0\, \forall x\, | x - a | < \delta \implies |f(x) - l| < \epsilon.x→alim​f(x)=l⟺∀ϵ>0∃δ>0∀x∣x−a∣<δ⟹∣f(x)−l∣<ϵ.
This definition has the feature that if lim⁡x→af(x)\lim_{x \to a}f(x)limx→a​f(x) exists then it's equal to f(a)f(a)f(a)
But that's not implied by the usual definition of limit

The usual definition is

lim⁡x→af(x)=l  ⟺  ∀ϵ>0 ∃δ>0 ∀x 0<∣x−a∣<δ  ⟹  ∣f(x)−l∣<ϵ.\lim_{x \to a}f(x) = l \iff \forall \epsilon > 0\, \exists \delta > 0\, \forall x\, 0 < | x - a | < \delta \implies |f(x) - l| < \epsilon.x→alim​f(x)=l⟺∀ϵ>0∃δ>0∀x0<∣x−a∣<δ⟹∣f(x)−l∣<ϵ.
see, e.g., Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limit_of_a_function#Functions_of_a_single_variable
Under the standard definition, if e.g. fff has a jump discontinuity at aaa then it is possible for lim⁡x→af(x)\lim_{x \to a}f(x)limx→a​f(x) to exist but to not equal f(a)f(a)f(a)
Under the usual definition of limit, the statement that limits commute when you have uniform convergence is not trivial and the uniform convergence is really required

Although the statement of the kata is no longer correct: it is possible to have a uniformly converging sequence of functions ⟨fn⟩\langle f_n \rangle⟨fn​⟩ converging to a function ggg where the limit of each fnf_nfn​ at aaa exists and the limit of ggg at aaa exists, but lim⁡n→inftyfn(a)\lim_{n \to infty} f_n(a)limn→infty​fn​(a) is not equal to lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x \to a}g(x)limx→a​g(x) (it is equal to g(a)g(a)g(a) of course, but the point is that g(a)g(a)g(a) may not be equal to lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x \to a}g(x)limx→a​g(x))

The right statement is to use the standard definition of limit of a function at a point and then say

If ⟨fn⟩\langle f_n\rangle⟨fn​⟩ is a sequence of functions R→R\mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}R→R which converges uniformly to a function ggg and if lim⁡x→afn(x)\lim_{x \to a}f_n(x)limx→a​fn​(x) exists for each nnn then lim⁡x→ag(x)\lim_{x \to a}g(x)limx→a​g(x) exists and is equal to lim⁡n→∞lim⁡x→afn(x)\lim_{n \to \infty}\lim_{x \to a}f_n(x)limn→∞​limx→a​fn​(x).
However, this statement does not match the formal statement in the kata
Anyway, I now see that some of the stuff in my original post in this thread is pretty confused
Basically I somehow didn't notice that the kata's definition of limit of a function at a point is wrong and I started also using this wrong definition
One solution would be to amend the kata's description to explain that the formal definition of limit used in the kata is not the standard one
And to make it clear that the kata's formal statement does not have much to do with uniform convergence and does not say that limits commute
I don't know if it's possible to change the kata itself (and not just the description). If so, I would change it to the statement above

import data.real.basic

/- We first define uniform convergence -/
def unif_convergence (f : ℕ → ℝ → ℝ) (g : ℝ → ℝ) :=
∀ ε > 0, ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n ≥ N, ∀ x : ℝ, abs (f n x - g x) < ε

/- Use the notation f → g to denote that the sequence fₙ converges uniformly to g
    You can type → by writing \hom -/
notation f `⟶` g := unif_convergence f g

/- We also define the notion of the limit of a function ℝ → ℝ at a point -/
def fun_limit (f : ℝ → ℝ) (a l) :=
∀ ε > 0, ∃ δ > 0, ∀ x : ℝ, x ≠ a → abs (x - a) < δ → abs (f x - l) < ε

/- And the notion of the limit of a sequence -/
def seq_limit (f : ℕ → ℝ) (l) :=
∀ ε > 0, ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n ≥ N, abs (f n - l) < ε

/- If fₙ converges uniformly to g and if lim_{x → a} fₙ(x) = lₙ for
    each n then lim_{x → a} g(x) exists and is equal to lim_{n → ∞} lₙ -/
theorem limits_commute (f : ℕ → ℝ → ℝ) (g : ℝ → ℝ) (l : ℕ → ℝ) (a : ℝ) :
    (f ⟶ g) → (∀ n, fun_limit (f n) a (l n)) →
    (∃ l', fun_limit g a l' ∧ seq_limit l l') := sorry
